required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Erlotinib 100mg or 150mg in Treating EGFR Mutation NSCLC Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Phase 3 Study of Erlotinib 100mg or 150mg in Treating EGFR Mutation Patients With Non-small Cell Lung Cancer

lead_sponsor.agency: The First Affiliated Hospital of Guangzhou Medical University

clinical_study.source: The First Affiliated Hospital of Guangzhou Medical University

oversight_info.authority: United States: Food and Drug Administration

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine whether 100mg erlotinib had similar effect compared with 150mg erlotinib in NSCLC patients with EGFR mutation in China.

detailed_description.textblock: In China it was confirmed that 150mg Erlotinib was effective in NSCLC patients wtih EGFR mutation, but reducing dose occurring in some patients because of the drug related side-effects. So we investigate that in Chinese patients with EGFR mutation whether low dose (100mg) Erlotinib had similar effect and low toxcities compared with standad dose (150mg) Erlotinib.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Treatment

secondary_outcome.measure: The objective response rate of disease
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Patients will be followed for an expected average of 6 months

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: The First Affiliated Hospital of Guangzhou Medical University
responsible_party.investigator_title: The First Affiliated Hospital of Guangzhou Medical Univers
